lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 17, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 17** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Dennis.Dennis.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Dennis.Dennis.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.
Dennis is a simple **command-line task manager** that helps you keep track of your to-dos, deadlines, and events.
It allows you to add, list, search, mark, unmark, and delete tasks—all from your terminal.
Dennis saves your tasks automatically to a file, so your list is restored every time you run it.
Dennis supports three types of tasks:
1. **Todo** – a simple task with just a description.
2. **Deadline** – a task with a due date/time.
3. **Event** – a task with a start and end date/time.
### Find Tasks by Keyword or Keyphrase
All tasks are saved automatically in a file at: ./data/dennis.txt
If the file or directory does not exist, Dennis creates it for you.
Uses OOP principles (Commands, Parser, TaskList, Storage, UI separation)

* This method is implemented by subclasses to define the specific
* behavior of the command (e.g., adding a task, marking a task, listing tasks).
* @param tasks   The TaskList that stores all current tasks.
* @param ui      The Ui for displaying messages to the user.
* @param storage The Storage used to save and load tasks from persistent storage.
public abstract void execute(TaskList tasks, Ui ui, Storage storage);

* Constructs a new Task with the given description.
* The task is initially marked as not done.
* @param description A brief description of the task.
* Returns the description of the task.
* Checks whether the task is completed.
* @return true if the task is done, false otherwise.
* Marks the task as not completed.
* Gets the type of the task (e.g., T, D, E).
* @return A string representing the task type.
* Converts the task into a save-friendly format for storage.
* @return A string formatted for saving the task to storage.
public String toSaveFormat() { return getType() + " | " + (isDone() ? "1" : "0") + " | " + getDescription(); }

* Shows the farewell message when the user ends Dennis.
System.out.println(" Thank god! I was wondering when you'd finish! Farewell from the one and only:\n");

* Prints all the tasks whose description contains the specific phrase to find.
* @param tasks An array list of all the tasks.

public void showMatchingTaskList(ArrayList<Task> tasks, String toFind) {
System.out.println(" No tasks containing {" + toFind + "} were found!");

System.out.println(" Ok, I added this task, make sure you actually do it!\n");
System.out.println(" OK, I've deleted this task, I hope you didn't just delete it because you don't feel like doing it!:\n");
System.out.println(" Alright, i've marked this task as FINALLY completed:\n");
System.out.println(" OK, I've marked this task as not done because you STILL haven't completed it:\n");
